message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Sjogren's syndrome. This autoimmune condition is most commonly associated with follicular hyperplasia pattern of reactive lymphadenitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's dry mouth and eyes suggest Sjögren's syndrome, which is associated with follicular hyperplasia of lymph nodes. Paracortical hyperplasia is associated with viral infections such as EBV and HIV, which are not mentioned in the patient's history. Diffuse hyperplasia and mixed B and T cell hyperplasia are non-specific patterns of lymphadenitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Dry mouth and eyes are symptoms of Sjogren's syndrome, which is associated with follicular hyperplasia of lymph nodes. Paracortical hyperplasia is often seen in viral infections, diffuse hyperplasia can be seen in autoimmune or lymphoproliferative disorders, and mixed B and T cell hyperplasia is often seen in reactive lymphoid hyperplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s dry mouth and eyes suggest Sjogren’s syndrome, which is commonly associated with Follicular hyperplasia of the lymph nodes. Paracortical hyperplasia is commonly associated with viral infections, Diffuse hyperplasia is seen in reactive lymphadenopathy, and Mixed B and T cell hyperplasia is seen in chronic inflammation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Sjögren syndrome, which is associated with follicular hyperplasia. Paracortical hyperplasia is associated with viral infections, whereas diffuse hyperplasia and mixed B and T cell hyperplasia can be seen in a variety of conditions.

Paracortical hyperplasia is associated with viral infections, diffuse hyperplasia can be seen in reactive lymphadenopathy, and mixed B and T cell hyperplasia is seen in HIV infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s dry oral mucosa and eyes suggest she has Sjogren syndrome, which is commonly associated with follicular hyperplasia pattern of reactive lymphadenitis. This pattern is associated with lymph node enlargement due to the proliferation of B cells in follicles.

The patient’s complaints of dry mouth and dry eyes suggest Sjögren’s syndrome, which is commonly associated with follicular hyperplasia of lymph nodes. Paracortical hyperplasia is associated with viral infections, diffuse hyperplasia is seen in immune reactions, and mixed B and T cell hyperplasia is seen in rheumatoid arthritis.
